title: The Best Beauty Advent Calendars of 2024 (So Far)
description: Fall has only just arrived, but that doesn’t mean we’re not already looking ahead to what this year’s holiday season will have to offer. (That is, if you’ve been good this year.) And while it may feel early — after all, Halloween is two months away — that hasn’t deterred brands from releasing some of their big-ticket holiday items. Case in point: Beauty-stuffed advent calendars.While these blockbuster sets usually come at a premium price point, that's for a few reasons: They tend to be limited in quantity, feature exquisite packaging, and contain myriad products, including full sizes or limited-edition shades. All that's to say that the beauty-filled advent calendars you'll find here are not only marvelous to ooh and aah at but also provide a surprisingly good value, given the ample contents inside. (Pro tip: Find a buddy to go halfsies with and divide the spoils.) And while advent calendars are inherently an exercise in patience, we won't tell if you open up all the teeny-tiny doors the day it arrives on your doorstep...At Refinery29, we’re here to help you navigate this overwhelming world of stuff. All of our market picks are independently selected and curated by the editorial team. All product details reflect the price and availability at the time of publication. If you buy or click on something we link to on our site, Refinery29 may earn commission. For more can't-miss shopping stories delivered straight to your inbox, sign up for our Most Wanted newsletter. Kiehl's 12 Mini Advent-Ures Gift SetKiehl's advent calendar is always one of the most popular sets of the gifting season, and this year is no exception. For $99, you can try $169 worth of Kiehl's classics, like Crème de Corps, Lip Balm #1, Creamy Eye Treatment, among many others.Kiehl's 12 Mini Advent-Ures Gift Set, $, available at Ulta BeautyDermalogica The Advent CalendarFor the aspiring aesthetician, Dermalogica's festive calendar is jam-packed with professional-grade skincare to get you glowing into the new year. Dermalogica The Advent Calendar, $, available at DermalogicaKylie Cosmetics Holiday Advent CalendarFor Kylie Cosmetics' advent calendar, the brand is serving twelve days of glam in the form of the brand's fan-favorite products: Plush lip oils, blush sticks, liquid lipsticks, and much more.Kylie Cosmetics Holiday Advent Calendar, $, available at Kylie CosmeticsRevolve Beauty 2024 Advent CalendarRevolve is perhaps best known for as a destination for party-ready fashion, but don't sleep on the retailer's beauty offerings. Case in point? This seriously stacked advent calendar, which includes a mix of full- and travel-size products from luxury brands like Dr. Dennis Gross, Elemis, Supergoop!, and more.Revolve Beauty 2024 Advent Calendar, $, available at RevolveVoluspa 12 Day Candle Advent CalendarWhen else but during the holiday season can you get 12 mini candles in one glorious box set? Unboxing them may last be fleeting, but hours of scent will take you all the way to 2025.Voluspa 12 Day Candle Advent Calendar, $, available at SephoraLaneige Manifest Glow: Best of Laneige SetCalling all K-beauty lovers: This dewy set of Laneige favorites includes six full-size and six mini versions of Laneige’s bestsellers. (If you're a fan of the brand's iconic Lip Sleeping Mask, you'll be pleased to hear that this advent calendar contains three different flavors to choose from.) Laneige Manifest Glow: Best of Laneige Set, $, available at LaneigeCharlotte Tilbury Beauty Treasure Chest Of LoveCharlotte Tilbury's advent calendar is always one that sells out — and fast. Don't miss out on getting this collectible heart-shaped treasure chest featuring drawers of glamorous makeup and skincare.Charlotte Tilbury CHARLOTTE'S BEAUTY TREASURE CHEST OF LOVE, $, available at Charlotte TilburyBeekman 1802 There's No Place Like Home Advent CalendarBeekman 1802's advent calendar features over $400 worth of goat milk-infused skincare, but also comes with a storybook starring (you guessed it) an adorable billy goat as they adventure back home for the holidays.Beekman 1802 There's No Place Like Home Advent Calendar, $, available at Beekman 1802Augustinus Bader The 12 Days of BaderI don't know many people willing to spend upwards of $600 on skincare, but if you are: This calendar is the way to do it. Augustinus Bader's first-ever advent calendar is filled with full- and travel-sized products, all powered with the brand's proprietary TFC8 complex.Augustinus Bader The 12 Days of Bader, $, available at Augustinus BaderAnthropologie Holiday Collection Beauty Advent CalendarAnthropologie's famed beauty calendar just dropped, and it might be the best one we've seen yet from the retailer. For just under $100, you get over $300 worth of products from all your favorite brands: First Aid Beauty, Supergoop, Nest, Elemis, among other storied company.Anthropologie Holiday Collection Beauty Advent Calendar, $, available at AnthropologieOlive & June 25 Days Of Mani MagicOlive & June's 2024 nail advent calendars just dropped — and are better than ever. Don't miss out on snapping up these jam-packed sets (one for Christmas and another for Hanukkah) of all things cuticle care, polish, stickers, and more.Olive & June 25 Days of Mani Magic Calendar, $, available at Olive & JuneOlive & June 8 Nights of Mani Magic Calendar, $, available at Olive & JuneDior Le 30 Montaigne Dior Beauty Advent CalendarIn a sea of beauty advent calendars, this $750 Dior version is a true work of art. The packaging is inspired by the maison's historic flagship at 30 Avenue Montaigne, and features a mix of Dior makeup, skincare, fragrance, and more.Dior Beauty Le 30 Montaigne Dior Beauty Advent Calendar, $, available at DiorBenefit Cosmetics Advent Calendar 2024We can always count on Benefit to dream up a whimsical take on holiday sets, and this year’s blockbuster advent calendar (reimagined as a shopping basket) is chock full of all your Bene-faves. Encased in 24 mini boxes, you’ll find a mix of full-size and miniature mascaras, blushes, lip tints, skincare, and much, much more.Benefit Cosmetics The Gorgeous Grocer, $, available at HSNLa Mer Advent Calendar 2024If you really want to knock the socks off of the skincare-obsessed friend on your list (maybe that’s you!), look no further than this La Mer advent calendar. With $720 worth of product inside, the lucky recipient is all but bound to enter 2025 looking as radiant as ever.La Mer The World of La Mer 12-Day Advent Calendar, $, available at Saks Fifth AvenueDiptyque Limited Edition Advent CalendarRevel in the spirit of Noël with Diptyque's made-in-France candles, body care, fragrances, which include something for everyone.Diptyque Limited Edition Advent Calendar, $, available at Neiman MarcusMaison Margiela Advent CalendarMaison Margiela Advent Calendar, $, available at SephoraSephora Collection Premium Advent CalendarThe destination for all things beauty knows a thing or two about gifting, so it's no surprise that Sephora's knocked it out of the park with its very own advent calendar. Featuring Sephora Collection faves, this gift set is chock-full of high-quality makeup and skincare at an accessible price point.Sephora Collection Premium Advent Calendar, $, available at SephoraLush Advent Calendar 2024​​Calling all Lushies: If you love nothing more than taking a gorgeously scented, candy-colored bath, then Lush’s advent calendars (yes, there are two this year) are for you. The High Street version (named after Lush’s first-ever store at 29 High Street in Poole, England) has 25 delightful bath goodies that bring the magic of Christmas to your tub. Then, there’s the Lush Advent Calendar, encased in a reusable trunk so you can restock it with anything from jewelry to makeup. Featuring eleven products that you’ll only find in the advent calendar (including fan faves from past holiday collections), this unique set is sure to encourage some much-needed self-care this holiday season.Lush Advent Calendar, $, available at LushLush 29 High Street Christmas Advent Calendar, $, available at LushThe Body Shop Advent Calendar 2024 Another beloved British bath brand (say that five times fast!) is The Body Shop, whose jam-packed advent calendar is filled to the brim with body butters, shower gels, and soaps galore. Plus, at just under $60, it's among the more affordable ones you'll find this season.The Body Shop Holiday Beauty Advent Calendar, $, available at AmazonL'Occitane 24 Days Of Beauty Advent CalendarGetting anything from French beauty brand L'Occitane is always a treat, but perhaps even more so when unboxed from a visually stunning advent calendar. Inside this luxe set, you'll find several full-size products alongside minis of the brand's most bestselling beauty treasures.L'Occitane 24 Days Of Beauty Advent Calendar, $, available at SephoraBobbi Brown Dazzle & Glow 12-Day Bestsellers Advent CalendarMakeup artist Bobbi Brown is known for her mastery of glowy, natural beauty — and this festive set includes everything you need to achieve her signature look: Multi-dimensional blush, skin-care minis, creamy eyeshadow sticks, and more.Bobbi Brown Dazzle & Glow 12-Day Bestsellers Advent Calendar, $, available at NordstromLiberty London Advent Calendar 2024If you can’t hop on a flight to Heathrow this holiday season, this advent calendar from Liberty London is the next best thing. Not only is the packaging utterly divine, but there’s over $1,500 (!) worth of luxury products inside from brands like Augustinus Bader, Byredo, and Sunday Riley among others.Liberty London The Liberty Beauty Advent Calendar 2024, $, available at Liberty LondonNeiman Marcus It doesn't get more fancy-pants than Neiman's, right? Indulge in the best of the best with this advent calendar featuring a mix of full- and miniature treasures from Augustinus Bader, Sisley-Paris, and many others.Shop Neiman MarcusNeiman Marcus Beauty Holiday Advent Calendar 2023, $, available at Neiman MarcusElemisThis skincare advent calendar is bursting at the seams with $749 worth of luxe products from British beauty brand Elemis, making it the ultimate gift for the beauty lover on your list.Shop ElemisElemis First Class Skincare Advent Calendar, $, available at ElemisSaks Fifth Avenue"A" is for Augustinus Bader, "B" is for Barbara Sturm, "C" is for Clé de Peau...is there any bougie brand left out of Saks' impossibly posh beauty advent calendar?Shop Saks Fifth AvenueSaks Fifth Avenue Saks 25 Days Of Beauty Advent Calendar, $, available at Saks Fifth AvenueNet-A-PorterNet-A-Porter's ultra-luxe 15-piece advent calendar contains a mix of full- and mini-sized treasures, including beauty products, accessories, and more. Plus, the lantern-shaped box is peppered with twinkling LED lights for a truly showstopping unboxing experience.Shop Net-A-PorterNet-A-Porter The Ultimate Gift Set, $, available at Net-A-PorterFreshThis blockbuster set from Fresh includes all the fan favorites the brand has to offer: Soy Face Cleanser, tinted lip balms, black tea-infused moisturizers, and more.Shop FreshFresh Advent Calendar Skincare Set, $, available at FreshUlta BeautyUlta girlies, this is the advent calendar for you. Inside the pretty gold box, you'll find 24 treasures from brands like Supergoop!, Sunday Riley, Drybar, and Briogeo, among other notable names.Shop Ulta BeautyUlta Beauty 24 Days of Self Care Advent Calendar, $, available at UltaDermstoreFor the skin-care fanatic on your list, you won't find a better gift than Dermstore's advent calendar, bursting at the seams with $765 (!) worth of products from 111Skin, Dr. Loretta, Skin Gym, and more.Dermstore 2022 Advent Calendar, $, available at DermStoreMACMAC never disappoints with its holiday offerings, and they've pulled out all the stops for its 2023 Frosted Frenzy Advent Calendar. Behind all 24 doors, you'll find MAC faves like the new Macstack Mascara, Powder Kiss lipstick, Lipglass, and much more.Shop MACMAC Cosmetics Frosted Frenzy Advent Calendar, $, available at MAC CosmeticsLike what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?Shopbop Beauty Is Here — & This Is What To Buy23 Graceful Gifts For Your Favorite LibraAugustinus Bader Just Launched A Lash & Brow Serum
author: Karina Hoshikawa

title: How OG Beauty Influencer JadeyWadey (Né Jadé Marie) Did A 180
description: When you’re a person online, your audience has a front-row seat to your evolution. Take the case of Jadé Marie — you might better recognize her by her online alias, JadeyWadey180 on Instagram and YouTube. The now holistic esthetician launched her career in beauty at 19 years old, sharing dramatic makeup transformations on YouTube and Instagram — false eyelashes, contour, the whole nine. She moved from Utah to L.A., grew her followers to over a million, and did the beauty influencer thing (brand trips, PR hauls, etc.). Then in late 2019, Jadé looked in the mirror and didn’t recognize herself. She realized the glam content and online persona she’d built for over a decade no longer resonated, so she endeavored to rebrand. Jadé describes her rebranding — she’s dropped the makeup entirely and is now a full-time esthetician specializing in holistic skincare — as a “coming home” to herself. Before anyone knew her as JadeyWadey, the makeup artist and influencer, Jadé was an esthetician in Utah. After graduating from cosmetology school, she worked in holistic wellness spas and clinical studios and learned about skincare (really, the base of makeup). But this happened to be the early 2010s, Instagram was still new, and makeup content was trending — people wanted the dramatic before and afters. “I’d share my skincare tips in my YouTube videos, but I didn’t feel like it was popping off at the time,” explains Jadé of the early days of beauty influencing on Instagram and YouTube. Makeup though? Her followers couldn’t get enough. As a savvy young entrepreneur and talented artist, Jadé followed the opportunities. “It was like this overnight transformation where JadeyWadey, really took off,” she says. “So for 10 years, I focused on the makeup side of things.” Here, Jadé opens up to R29 about the “really big pivot” that changed her life and career, how being online eroded her sense of self, the wellness tips she learned in her journey back, and how they influenced her to create her skincare brand, JADÉ Complexions. DashDividers_1_500x100 What was it like being an OG beauty influencer? How did being online at such a young age affect your self-perception? When I moved to L.A., I felt pressured to stay up with always looking glamorous and covering myself with makeup. I always struggled with this idea of perfection. When you’re on social media at a super young age, it does something to you. There are all these filters, FaceTune. You fall into this place where you have to keep up appearances. With makeup and enhancements, I tried to mirror what I thought I looked like online. But in my real life, it wasn’t who I was. You say you experienced a “really big pivot” in your life. What was that change? I was deep in the beauty industry — and this was right before 2020 — and I got to a point where I did not recognize myself anymore. I felt like I needed a total rebranding to get back to the core of why I got into the industry in the first place, which was to help other people feel comfortable in their own skin. Ironically, the more popular I was online, the less comfortable I felt in my skin. “The more popular I was online, the less comfortable I felt in my skin. ” Jadé Marie What practices and lifestyle changes helped you get back to yourself? I retreated for a bit. I was less focused on social media because I felt that taking care of myself was the most important thing. I started to dabble in mental health practices: meditation, affirmation, and holistic practices that I was taught at a young age when I first learned about skincare. I became plant-based. I did a 180. The transformation was so extreme; I saw it in my skin but in my mind, too. I was like, how can I get this methodology out to other people? How do you infuse these mindfulness and mental health practices into your facials? In my private skincare studio in West Hollywood, I have a Signature 180 Facial that starts with breathwork. I play a meditation. There’s also a sound bath. It’s more than a facial, it’s an experience for the skin and the senses. What does your social media content look like today? I knew it would be a big risk to do a whole pivot because people followed me for the makeup, but my passion and first love has always been skincare. So bringing that back and reviving the esthetician side of my career was honestly like coming home to myself. In my YouTube series, I talk about meditation and all the aspects that helped me on my own personal journey, mixed with skin education. “I knew it would be a big risk to do a whole pivot because people followed me for the makeup, but my passion and first love has always been skincare.”Jadé Marie What’s your skincare routine? I’ve never felt that you need a 10-step routine. I’m a big believer in getting facial treatments and doing them yourself. Through my YouTube series, I teach viewers how to do at-home facial treatments with minimal products. I’m a big believer in having an amazing exfoliator to help resurface dead skin cells and help with cell turnover. I love having an oil for self-massage, and a gua sha tool. Speaking of exfoliation, you just released your first skincare product, JADÉ Complexions Crystalline Marine Facial Polish. What inspired it? My little brother Stephen. He was dealing with a bunch of different skincare concerns: cystic acne, uneven texture, clogged pores, hyperpigmentation. I would give him facials once a month, but his skin wasn’t getting better. So I started mixing him custom blends. Over time, this little mask formula I made was helping his skin so much. I was like, ‘We might have something here.’ I never thought I was going to be creating a brand. But from the results I saw with my brother’s skin, I knew I wanted to help other people with similar concerns. It’s a physical and chemical exfoliant. On the physical side, it has a gentle amount of baltic gem powder, a tree resin that helps polish away dead skin cells. On the chemical side, it has glycolic and salicylic acid to help with brightening, acne, and breakouts. I also found this unique algae called Jade Alga, sourced from France, that’s very hydrating. [Ed note: The Facial Polish comes with an affirmation: ‘I am ready to shed what no longer serves me. I welcome softness.’] How do you use the polish? I use the facial polish as a 10-minute mask two times a week, at night. It smooths out uneven texture, dissolves pore congestion in clogged areas like the T-zone, and helps alleviate breakouts quickly. You could also use it as a pimple spot treatment or a clarifying cleanser, mixing this with an oil cleanser to enhance your cleanse experience. Exfoliation is so important if you want your other products to penetrate and work into your skin. If you layer serums and oils on top of dead skin cells, they’re not going deep enough into the epidermis to do anything for you to see results. You have over a decade of experience as a makeup artist. So I’m curious, what does your makeup routine look like now? It’s honestly become very simplified, because of this product. In the past, I struggled with breakouts and clogged pores, so I felt the need to add a ton of glamour. People probably miss the glam stuff I used to do…but now I love a good glowy, dewy tinted sunscreen look, minimal eye makeup, and lip balm. What advice would you offer young beauty influencers today? What would you want them to take away from your experience? I’m very open about speaking about the negative effects that social media can have. I think the biggest thing is to be authentic and not feel like you have to change yourself. The world needs that. The world needs to see the true us, unveiled and unhidden.  Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?Sarah Creal Beauty Is a Gift for 40-Plus SkinMy Skin Always Looks Worse After A Facial — Why?The One Tweak That Had The Most Impact On Our Skin
author: Megan Decker

title: Glamnetic's Magnetic Liner and Lashes Are Easy to Apply and Look Natural
description: I've only applied magnetic lashes once because eyeliner and I don't usually go together - at least not yet. Every time I try, my hands seem to have a mind of their own, and I end up getting frustrated and giving up. And let's not even talk about using glue to apply lashes. All my friends keep telling me that practice makes perfect, but the perfectionist in me wants to get it right on the first try, and that hasn't been the case. When I had the opportunity to review Glamnetic's viral magnetic lashes, I knew this was the push I needed to finally learn how to apply eyeliner. I tested four magnetic lashes - Glamnetic's Virgo Lashes ($30), VIP Lashes ($30), Venus Lashes ($30), Baby Girl Lashes ($30) - and I also used the brand's Magnetic Eyeliner Pen ($38) in black. I did try applying the eyeliner and lashes on my own, and while my application was messy, the lashes held up pretty well and they looked better than I expected. So, for all the girlies who struggle with applying lashes or eyeliner, this one's for you. Keep scrolling to read my full review of Glamnetic's Magnetic Eyelashes and Magnetic Eyeliner Pen. About Glamnetic's Magnetic Eyelashes + Magnetic Eyeliner Pen The lashes are made from a vegan-friendly synthetic fiber. The lashes come with a special magnetic case for safe-keeping. The magnetic liner is sold separately. There are a range of lashes to choose from, depending on if you like a more natural everyday lash or if you want a more dramatic look. There are two magnetic liners to choose from: black and brown. What I Like About Glamnetic's Magnetic Eyelashes + Magnetic Eyeliner Pen First and foremost, even though they're magnetic, the lashes slide into place after a little maneuvering to get them exactly where you want them. I didn't expect them to feel as secure as they did. I also appreciated that with some of the lashes I received, there was a small eyelash anchor included for added security. It's a small cluster lash that you can place on the underside of your magnetic lashes to secure them even more. Although I didn't try it because the lashes felt secure enough to me, I appreciated the thoughtfulness behind that addition. I also liked how natural all the lashes looked. Once they were on, I couldn't tell they were magnetic - and that's the beauty of the product. Honestly, that's what sold me! It was such a seamless process, despite my being a beginner at eyeliner. I also loved how you could easily switch out the lashes if you wanted to try a new set. In the past, when I've worn lashes with glue, I dreaded removing them. But with magnetic lashes, you literally just pull them off, and there's no damage done to your natural lashes. How To Use the Glamnetic Magnetic Eyelashes + Magnetic Eyeliner Pen First, shake the magnetic eyeliner pen to ensure the tip is saturated with product. Then, apply the liner to your upper lash line. I didn't do a winged eyeliner, but that's up to you on whatever your personal preference is. Next, grab the magnetic lash of your choice and place it along the area where you applied the eyeliner. Position it as close to your natural lashes as possible to ensure a seamless look. If you notice a gap between your natural lashes and the magnetic lash, pull them down and adjust to your liking. What To Consider Before Trying the Glamnetic Magnetic Eyelashes + Magnetic Eyeliner Pen Honestly, the only reservations I had about trying the magnetic lashes and eyeliner was the eyeliner. Because I'm very much a beginner, I assumed that it would be hard to get the lashes to attach to my shoddy liner job after I tried them on my own - but that wasn't the case at all. Who Is the Glamnetic Magnetic Eyelashes + Magnetic Eyeliner Pen Best For I think I've proven that it's best for anyone looking to try out magnetic lashes, no matter your skill level! If you're someone who loves a 10- or 15-minute makeup routine and thinks applying lashes the traditional way (using glue) would take up too much of your time, then Glamnetic lashes are definitely for you. And if you're a seasoned pro, they'll be a breeze to put on. Rating:
author: Shari Straker

title: Does Travis Kelce Have Any Tattoos? Fans Are Wondering
description: Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift have been all that people can talk about ever since the singer started to be a regular at the Chiefs games (and sat with the football player's mom). Their romance, which presumably began sometime around September 2023, has been a whirlwind to watch, with each star making headlines every time they supported the other's career endeavors. Kelce accompanied Swift on The Eras Tour and Swift followed Kelce all the way to the Super Bowl where his team secured a win. Naturally, this has led to an influx of new football fans curious about Swift's potential beau - more specifically, Kecle's tattoo collection. Searches for "Travis Kelce tattoos" have reached new heights, as people clamor to learn more about the three-time Super Bowl champion. Though he is well-known for expressing himself via his fashion choices, Kelce has no publicly known tattoos at this time. in a July 2024 episode of Jason Kelce and Travis Kelce's podcast, "New Heights," the two talked about how they had previously discussed getting a family crest, but did not have any current plans to get any ink. Still, that isn't to say that there aren't any Kelce-inspired designs out there. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Travis Kelce (@killatrav) Famously, after losing a bet to both Kelce and his teammate Patrick Mahomes, musician Post Malone tattooed both their signatures on his arm backstage at a concert. "He has a tattoo artist literally in the room," Mahomes told "GQ about the ordeal." "I'm like, 'Dude, you do not actually have to get a tattoo of our autographs.'" It's not clear whether Kelce has any interest in getting some body art of his own; Swift's tattoo collection is similarly nonexistent. But who knows what the future holds for our favorite it-couple. Ariel Baker is the assistant editor for PS Beauty. Her areas of expertise include celebrity news, beauty trends, and product reviews. She has additional bylines with Essence and Forbes Vetted.
author: Ariel Baker
